articles.title: The summer months have traditionally been a very active time for the SJAA.
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) had a busy summer, marked by board elections and the appointment of new officers, including Kevin Medlock as president. Upcoming activities include new star party sites, a grazing occultation expedition, and a potential observing session at the Santa Clara County Fair. The article also provides contact information for board members, details membership renewals, and announces a lecture by Bob Truax.

articles.title: UMUNHUM
articles.summary: The article announces Mt. Umunhum as a new, promising observing site, scouted by Bob Scott and Wolf Hanisch, replacing Henry Coe State Park for the August 9th star party. It provides detailed instructions for accessing the site, including gate combinations and operation, and notes potential observing areas within the base.

articles.title: The Glasspool Site Star Party
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) held a star party on July 12th at Dick Glasspool's property in the Santa Cruz Mountains, attended by about twenty members. Despite some difficulties with leveling telescopes and fog rolling in around midnight, participants enjoyed observing with various instruments, noting decent sky conditions given the site's proximity to San Jose. The SJAA extended thanks to Glasspool for his generous hospitality.

articles.title: THE PICNIC
articles.summary: The annual SJAA picnic at Cupertino's Portal Park gathered about 50 members for a day of food, games, and club business. Attendees enjoyed a potluck, flying kites, frisbee wars, and sunspot observing, along with the presentation of the Dr. A.E. Gregory Award to Kevin Medlock and the installation of new officers. The event was highly enjoyable and concluded at dusk.

articles.title: Want Ads
articles.summary: This document features a series of "Want Ads" for various used astronomical equipment. Items for sale include an Edmund 6" equatorial mount with a clock drive, Bushnell 7X50 binoculars, a C-90 spotting scope, and a comprehensive 6" f/8 reflector setup complete with mount, accessories, and a celestial atlas. Each listing provides a price and contact information for potential buyers.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article provides an update on comet visibility, noting no bright comets are currently visible but predicting two to three brighter than magnitude 10 by autumn. It details the recent discoveries and recoveries of Comets Torres (1980e), Periodic Comet Brooks 2 (1980f), and Periodic Comet Stephan-Oterma (1980g) in Chile. Additionally, it includes positional data and magnitude estimates for Comet Forbes.

articles.title: Comets in Their Eyes:
articles.summary: This article highlights notable individuals and their contributions to comet and asteroid discovery. It details Reverend Joel Metcalf's six comet and sixty asteroid discoveries in the early 1900s, and Doug Berger's accidental discovery of Comet Kobayashi-Berger-Milon in 1975, a significant first for American amateur astronomers in seven years. The text also briefly introduces Merlin Kohler, another casual comet hunter.

articles.summary: An electronic technician named Merlin discovered something in Corona Borealis in September 1977, using an 8" Dynamax telescope. His discovery was not the result of a systematic comet-hunting program, but rather from casually sweeping the sky for a few minutes after each observing session.

articles.title: SJAA PROFILES
articles.summary: This article presents preliminary results from an SJAA member survey, revealing that 8-inch telescopes are the most popular, deep-sky observing is the main interest, and workshops received positive feedback. Based on these findings, the club plans to establish new classes for telescope making, astrophotography, and night sky observing, and is seeking a volunteer to organize a variable star observing team. Additionally, the report includes details about an upcoming Aldebaran occultation on August 5th.

articles.title: SJAA
articles.summary: This document details a lunar graze event organized by SJAA, scheduled for August 19-20, 1980, between Soledad and Greenfield. It provides comprehensive instructions for participants, including location, specific observation times, communication protocols (CB Channel 14), and contact information for weather and site updates. The event is expected to feature multiple occultation events due to the moon's profile.

articles.title: Many handy numbers and neat stuff
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed collection of astronomical data, likely pertaining to a specific observing event such as a lunar graze. It includes various angles (graze position, vertex, cusp, Watts), twilight and moonset times, precise coordinates and characteristics for the star 24 Scorpii and the Moon, and site-specific longitude, latitude, and elevation. A diagram depicting moon phases and pole positions is also referenced.

articles.title: USING A HAND-BRACED, LOW-POWER NEWTONIAN TELESCOPE
articles.summary: The article details the author's successful use of a hand-braced, low-power 6-inch f/4.7 Newtonian telescope, without a traditional mount, for deep-sky observation. Emphasizing portability and ease of setup, the author explains a technique for steadying the telescope by bracing it against solid surfaces, making it effective for finding objects and observing broad, low-surface brightness targets. This method has allowed the author to observe over 400 deep-sky objects, including Messier objects and faint galaxies, highlighting its utility as an inexpensive and highly portable observing solution.

articles.title: LOGO CONTEST
articles.summary: The SJAA is holding a logo contest, inviting its general membership to vote for a new design. Members can cast their ballots at upcoming general meetings or indoor star parties, with the winner scheduled to be announced in the October bulletin.

articles.title: LOGO CONTEST
articles.summary: This document outlines a logo contest for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), presenting six distinct design options for a new organizational logo. Readers are prompted to select their preferred design, indicating the document's purpose is to gather feedback or announce the selection of a new logo.
